title: Quadratic Functions & Graphs
description: Master quadratic functions, their graphs, and applications including maximum/minimum problems
description_zh: 掌握二次函数、图形及其应用，包括最大/最小值问题
objectives: Graph quadratic functions and identify key features (vertex, axis of symmetry, y-intercept)
Solve quadratic equations by factorization, completing the square, and formula
Apply quadratic functions to real-world maximum/minimum problems
Understand the relationship between algebraic and graphical representations
objectives_zh: 绘制二次函数图形并识别关键特征（顶点、对称轴、y截距）
用因式分解、配方法和公式求解二次方程
应用二次函数解决实际最大/最小值问题
理解代数表示与图形表示之间的关系

sections.title: Quadratic Function Basics
sections.content:
A quadratic function has the form: y = ax² + bx + c, where a ≠ 0

Key features:
- Parabola shape: Opens upward if a > 0, downward if a < 0
- Vertex: The turning point (maximum or minimum)
- Axis of symmetry: x = -b/(2a)
- y-intercept: The point where x = 0, which is (0, c)

Example: y = x² - 4x + 3
- Opens upward (a = 1 > 0)
- Axis of symmetry: x = -(-4)/(2×1) = 2
- Vertex at x = 2: y = 4 - 8 + 3 = -1, so vertex is (2, -1)
- y-intercept: (0, 3)

sections.title: Solving Quadratic Equations
sections.content:
Three methods to solve ax² + bx + c = 0:

1. Factorization:
x² - 5x + 6 = 0
(x - 2)(x - 3) = 0
x = 2 or x = 3

2. Completing the Square:
x² + 6x + 5 = 0
x² + 6x = -5
x² + 6x + 9 = -5 + 9
(x + 3)² = 4
x + 3 = ±2
x = -1 or x = -5

3. Quadratic Formula:
x = [-b ± √(b² - 4ac)] / (2a)

Discriminant (b² - 4ac) tells us:
- If > 0: Two real solutions
- If = 0: One repeated solution
- If < 0: No real solutions

sections.title: Maximum/Minimum Problems
sections.content:
Quadratic functions are used to solve optimization problems.

Example: A farmer has 100m of fencing to enclose a rectangular plot against a wall. Find dimensions for maximum area.

Let width = x meters
Length = 100 - 2x meters (only 3 sides need fencing)
Area A = x(100 - 2x) = 100x - 2x²
A = -2x² + 100x

Vertex at x = -100/(2×-2) = 25
Maximum area when x = 25m, length = 50m
Maximum area = 25 × 50 = 1250 m²

Singapore context: A hawker wants to use 60m of divider to create the largest rectangular stall space.

title: Algebraic Fractions
description: Simplify, add, subtract, multiply, and divide algebraic fractions and solve equations involving fractions
description_zh: 化简、加减乘除代数分式，求解含分式的方程
objectives: Simplify algebraic fractions by factorization
Add and subtract algebraic fractions with different denominators
Multiply and divide algebraic fractions
Solve equations involving algebraic fractions
objectives_zh: 用因式分解化简代数分式
加减不同分母的代数分式
乘除代数分式
求解含代数分式的方程

sections.title: Simplifying Algebraic Fractions
sections.content:
Simplify by factorizing numerator and denominator:

Example 1:
(x² - 9) / (x² + 6x + 9)
= (x + 3)(x - 3) / (x + 3)²
= (x - 3) / (x + 3)

Example 2:
(2x² + 5x - 3) / (2x² - x - 1)
= (2x - 1)(x + 3) / (2x + 1)(x - 1)

Key: Always factorize first, then cancel common factors.
Note: State restrictions (values that make denominator zero).

sections.title: Operations with Algebraic Fractions
sections.content:
Addition/Subtraction: Find LCD (Lowest Common Denominator)

2/x + 3/(x+1)
= [2(x+1) + 3x] / [x(x+1)]
= (2x + 2 + 3x) / [x(x+1)]
= (5x + 2) / [x(x+1)]

Multiplication: Multiply numerators and denominators
(x² - 4)/(x + 3) × (x + 3)/(x + 2)
= [(x-2)(x+2)]/(x+3) × (x+3)/(x+2)
= (x - 2)/1 = x - 2

Division: Multiply by reciprocal
(x + 1)/(x - 1) ÷ (x² - 1)/(x)
= (x + 1)/(x - 1) × x/(x² - 1)
= (x + 1)/(x - 1) × x/[(x+1)(x-1)]
= x/(x - 1)²

sections.title: Equations with Fractions
sections.content:
To solve equations with algebraic fractions:
1. Find LCD
2. Multiply both sides by LCD to eliminate fractions
3. Solve resulting equation
4. Check solutions (reject values that make denominator zero)

Example:
3/x + 2/(x-1) = 5

LCD = x(x - 1)
Multiply: 3(x-1) + 2x = 5x(x-1)
3x - 3 + 2x = 5x² - 5x
5x - 3 = 5x² - 5x
0 = 5x² - 10x + 3

Use quadratic formula to solve.

title: Coordinate Geometry
description: Study gradients, equations of straight lines, parallel and perpendicular lines, and applications
description_zh: 学习斜率、直线方程、平行线和垂直线及其应用
objectives: Calculate gradient of a line given two points
Find equations of lines in various forms (y = mx + c, ax + by = c)
Identify parallel and perpendicular lines using gradients
Solve problems involving coordinate geometry in real contexts
objectives_zh: 计算给定两点的直线斜率
求不同形式的直线方程（y = mx + c, ax + by = c）
用斜率识别平行线和垂直线
解决实际情境中的坐标几何问题

sections.title: Gradient and Equations of Lines
sections.content:
Gradient (slope) m = (y₂ - y₁)/(x₂ - x₁)

Equation of a line:
1. Gradient-intercept form: y = mx + c
   - m is gradient
   - c is y-intercept

2. Point-slope form:
   Given point (x₁, y₁) and gradient m:
   y - y₁ = m(x - x₁)

3. General form: ax + by + c = 0

Example: Find equation of line through (2, 5) and (4, 9)
m = (9 - 5)/(4 - 2) = 4/2 = 2
Using y - y₁ = m(x - x₁):
y - 5 = 2(x - 2)
y - 5 = 2x - 4
y = 2x + 1

sections.title: Parallel & Perpendicular Lines
sections.content:
Parallel Lines: Same gradient
If line 1 has gradient m₁ and line 2 has gradient m₂,
Parallel if m₁ = m₂

Example: y = 3x + 2 and y = 3x - 5 are parallel (both have m = 3)

Perpendicular Lines: Product of gradients = -1
If perpendicular, m₁ × m₂ = -1
Or m₂ = -1/m₁

Example: y = 2x + 1 and y = -½x + 3 are perpendicular
(2 × -½ = -1)

Singapore context: Two MRT lines cross at right angles. If one line has equation y = 3x + 5, find the equation of the perpendicular line passing through (6, 2).

sections.title: Applications
sections.content:
Real-world applications:

1. Distance problems: Find if point lies on a line
2. Area of triangles using coordinates
3. Midpoint and section formulas
4. Singapore contexts:
   - Planning roads at right angles
   - Calculating land area on coordinate grid
   - GPS coordinates and navigation

Example: A park has corners at A(0,0), B(8,0), C(8,6), D(0,6).
Find:
a) Area of park = length × width = 8 × 6 = 48 units²
b) Equation of diagonal AC: passes through (0,0) and (8,6)
   m = 6/8 = 3/4
   y = (3/4)x

title: Similar & Congruent Triangles
title_zh: 相似三角形与全等三角形
description: Prove congruence and similarity of triangles, solve problems using these properties
description_zh: 证明三角形全等和相似，运用这些性质解题
objectives: Prove triangle congruence using SSS, SAS, ASA, AAS criteria
Prove triangle similarity using AA, SAS, SSS criteria
Apply properties of similar triangles to solve problems
Use congruence and similarity in geometric proofs
objectives_zh: 用SSS、SAS、ASA、AAS准则证明三角形全等
用AA、SAS、SSS准则证明三角形相似
应用相似三角形性质解题
在几何证明中运用全等和相似

sections.title: Congruent Triangles
sections.content:
Two triangles are congruent if they have the same shape and size.

Congruence Criteria:
1. SSS: Three sides equal
2. SAS: Two sides and included angle equal
3. ASA: Two angles and included side equal
4. AAS: Two angles and one side equal
5. RHS: Right angle, hypotenuse, and one side equal

Notation: △ABC ≅ △DEF means triangle ABC is congruent to triangle DEF

Corresponding parts:
- AB = DE, BC = EF, AC = DF
- ∠A = ∠D, ∠B = ∠E, ∠C = ∠F

Proof structure:
1. State what to prove
2. Identify congruent parts
3. State which criterion (SSS, SAS, etc.)
4. Conclude triangles are congruent

sections.title: Similar Triangles
sections.content:
Two triangles are similar if they have the same shape (not necessarily same size).

Similarity Criteria:
1. AA (Angle-Angle): Two angles equal
2. SAS: Two sides proportional and included angle equal
3. SSS: Three sides proportional

Notation: △ABC ~ △DEF means triangle ABC is similar to triangle DEF

Properties:
- Corresponding angles are equal
- Corresponding sides are proportional: AB/DE = BC/EF = AC/DF = k (scale factor)

Example: If △ABC ~ △DEF with scale factor 2:
- If AB = 6cm, then DE = 3cm
- If area of △ABC = 20cm², then area of △DEF = 20/4 = 5cm²
  (Area ratio = k²)

sections.title: Applications of Similarity
sections.content:
Applications:

1. Finding heights indirectly:
A tree casts a 15m shadow when a 2m pole casts a 3m shadow.
Tree height: 2/3 = h/15, so h = 10m

2. Map scales:
On a map with scale 1:50000, two buildings are 8cm apart.
Actual distance = 8 × 50000 = 400000cm = 4km

3. Singapore context:
Marina Bay Sands has three 55-storey towers. A scale model uses ratio 1:500.
If actual tower is 200m tall, model height = 200/500 = 0.4m = 40cm

4. Enlargement problems:
A photo is enlarged from 10cm × 15cm to 20cm × 30cm.
Scale factor = 2
Original area = 150cm², New area = 150 × 4 = 600cm²

title: Trigonometry
description: Learn sine, cosine, tangent ratios and apply to solve problems in right-angled triangles
description_zh: 学习正弦、余弦、正切比，应用于求解直角三角形问题
objectives: Define and use sine, cosine, and tangent ratios
Solve problems involving angles of elevation and depression
Apply trigonometry to real-world problems (heights, distances)
Use calculator to find trigonometric values and angles
objectives_zh: 定义和使用正弦、余弦、正切比
解决涉及仰角和俯角的问题
应用三角学于实际问题（高度、距离）
用计算器求三角函数值和角度

sections.title: Trigonometric Ratios
sections.content:
In a right-angled triangle with angle θ:

SOH-CAH-TOA:
- sin θ = Opposite / Hypotenuse
- cos θ = Adjacent / Hypotenuse
- tan θ = Opposite / Adjacent

Example: Right triangle with hypotenuse 10cm, opposite 6cm, adjacent 8cm
sin θ = 6/10 = 0.6
cos θ = 8/10 = 0.8
tan θ = 6/8 = 0.75

Special angles (to memorize):
θ     30°   45°   60°
sin   1/2   √2/2  √3/2
cos   √3/2  √2/2  1/2
tan   √3/3  1     √3

Using calculator:
Find sin 35° ≈ 0.574
Find angle: if sin θ = 0.5, then θ = sin⁻¹(0.5) = 30°

sections.title: Angles of Elevation & Depression
sections.content:
Angle of Elevation: Looking UP from horizontal
Angle of Depression: Looking DOWN from horizontal

Both measured from horizontal line.

Example: From a point 50m from the base of a building, the angle of elevation to the top is 40°.
Find building height.

tan 40° = h/50
h = 50 × tan 40°
h ≈ 50 × 0.839
h ≈ 42m

Singapore example: From the top of Marina Bay Sands (200m), the angle of depression to a boat is 25°. Find distance from building to boat.

tan 25° = 200/d
d = 200/tan 25°
d ≈ 200/0.466
d ≈ 429m

sections.title: Applications of Trigonometry
sections.content:
Real-world applications:

1. Finding heights of buildings/trees
2. Navigation and bearings
3. Construction and engineering
4. Surveying land

Singapore contexts:

1. HDB blocks: From 80m away, angle of elevation to top floor is 35°. Find block height.
   h = 80 × tan 35° ≈ 56m

2. Cable car: Singapore Cable Car travels at 15° angle. If horizontal distance is 1000m, find height difference.
   h = 1000 × tan 15° ≈ 268m

3. Esplanade roof: The curved roof creates a 20° angle. If base width is 120m, find maximum height at center.
   h = 60 × tan 20° ≈ 22m

4. Bearing problems: A ship sails 50km on bearing 060°, then 30km on bearing 150°. Find final distance from start.

title: Mensuration: 3D Shapes
description: Calculate volumes and surface areas of prisms, cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres
description_zh: 计算棱柱、圆柱、棱锥、圆锥和球体的体积和表面积
objectives: Calculate volumes and surface areas of prisms and cylinders
Calculate volumes and surface areas of pyramids, cones, and spheres
Solve problems involving composite 3D shapes
Apply mensuration to real-world problems
objectives_zh: 计算棱柱和圆柱的体积和表面积
计算棱锥、圆锥和球体的体积和表面积
解决涉及复合立体图形的问题
应用测量于实际问题

sections.title: Prisms & Cylinders
sections.content:
Prism: Volume = Base Area × Height
Surface Area = 2 × Base Area + Perimeter × Height

Cylinder (circular prism):
Volume = πr²h
Curved Surface Area = 2πrh
Total Surface Area = 2πr² + 2πrh = 2πr(r + h)

Example: Water tank (cylinder) radius 2m, height 5m
Volume = π(2)²(5) = 20π ≈ 62.8 m³
If 1 m³ = 1000 liters, tank holds 62,800 liters

Triangular Prism:
Base area = ½ × base × height
Volume = (½ × base × height) × length

Singapore context: A rectangular HDB water tank is 3m × 2m × 1.5m. Volume = 3 × 2 × 1.5 = 9m³ = 9000 liters.

sections.title: Pyramids, Cones & Spheres
sections.content:
Pyramid: Volume = ⅓ × Base Area × Height

Cone:
Volume = ⅓πr²h
Curved Surface Area = πrl (where l = slant height)
Total Surface Area = πr² + πrl = πr(r + l)

Sphere:
Volume = ⅔πr³
Surface Area = 4πr²

Relationships:
- Cone volume = ⅓ cylinder volume (same base and height)
- Pyramid volume = ⅓ prism volume (same base and height)

Example: Ice cream cone, radius 3cm, height 10cm
Volume = ⅓π(3)²(10) = 30π ≈ 94.2 cm³

Example: Basketball radius 12cm
Volume = ⅔π(12)³ ≈ 7238 cm³
Surface Area = 4π(12)² ≈ 1810 cm²

sections.title: Composite 3D Shapes
sections.content:
For composite shapes:
1. Break down into simpler shapes
2. Calculate volume/surface area of each part
3. Add or subtract as needed

Example: A silo consists of a cylinder (radius 5m, height 12m) topped with a hemisphere (radius 5m).

Volume:
Cylinder = πr²h = π(5)²(12) = 300π m³
Hemisphere = ½ × ⅔πr³ = ⅓π(5)³ = 125π/3 m³
Total = 300π + 125π/3 = (900π + 125π)/3 = 1025π/3 ≈ 1072 m³

Singapore contexts:
- Esplanade theatres (spherical sections)
- Marina Bay Sands rooftop pool (rectangular prism)
- Cone-shaped traffic cones
- Spherical water storage tanks

Practical: A cylindrical water tank (r=3m, h=8m) costs $150 per m³. Total cost = π(3)²(8) × 150 ≈ $33,929

title: Probability
description: Calculate probabilities of single and combined events, use tree diagrams and Venn diagrams
description_zh: 计算单一和组合事件的概率，使用树状图和维恩图
objectives: Calculate probability of single events and combined events
Use tree diagrams to find probabilities of successive events
Apply addition and multiplication rules for probability
Solve real-world probability problems
objectives_zh: 计算单一事件和组合事件的概率
用树状图求连续事件的概率
应用概率的加法和乘法规则
解决实际概率问题

sections.title: Basic Probability
sections.content:
Probability = Number of favorable outcomes / Total number of possible outcomes

P(A) = n(A) / n(S), where S is sample space

Properties:
- 0 ≤ P(A) ≤ 1
- P(certain event) = 1
- P(impossible event) = 0
- P(not A) = 1 - P(A)

Example: Rolling a die
P(getting 4) = 1/6
P(even number) = 3/6 = 1/2
P(number > 4) = 2/6 = 1/3
P(not getting 6) = 5/6

Singapore context: In a class of 40 students, 15 take Chinese, 12 take Malay, 8 take Tamil, 5 take French.
P(randomly selected student takes Chinese) = 15/40 = 3/8

sections.title: Combined Events & Rules
sections.content:
Addition Rule (OR):
P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B)
If mutually exclusive: P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B)

Multiplication Rule (AND):
Independent events: P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B)

Example: Drawing cards
P(King or Queen) = 4/52 + 4/52 = 8/52 = 2/13 (mutually exclusive)
P(Heart or King) = 13/52 + 4/52 - 1/52 = 16/52 = 4/13 (not mutually exclusive)

Example: Tossing two coins
P(both heads) = 1/2 × 1/2 = 1/4 (independent)

With replacement: Events are independent
Without replacement: Events are dependent

Example: Bag with 5 red, 3 blue balls
With replacement: P(2 red) = 5/8 × 5/8 = 25/64
Without replacement: P(2 red) = 5/8 × 4/7 = 20/56 = 5/14

sections.title: Tree Diagrams
sections.content:
Tree diagrams show all possible outcomes for successive events.

Steps:
1. Draw branches for first event with probabilities
2. From each outcome, draw branches for second event
3. Multiply along branches for combined probability
4. Add probabilities for different paths to same outcome

Example: Two-child family (B=Boy, G=Girl)
First child: P(B)=1/2, P(G)=1/2
Second child: P(B)=1/2, P(G)=1/2

Possible outcomes: BB, BG, GB, GG (each 1/4)
P(exactly 1 boy) = P(BG) + P(GB) = 1/4 + 1/4 = 1/2
P(at least 1 boy) = P(BB) + P(BG) + P(GB) = 3/4

Singapore context: MRT train on time 85% of time. Taking train 2 days.
P(on time both days) = 0.85 × 0.85 = 0.7225 = 72.25%
P(late at least once) = 1 - 0.7225 = 0.2775 = 27.75%

title: Statistical Data Analysis
description: Analyze data using mean, median, mode, range, standard deviation, and interpret statistical graphs
description_zh: 用平均数、中位数、众数、极差、标准差分析数据，解读统计图表
objectives: Calculate and interpret mean, median, mode, and range
Understand and calculate standard deviation as measure of spread
Create and interpret box plots and histograms
Compare data sets using statistical measures
objectives_zh: 计算和解释平均数、中位数、众数和极差
理解和计算标准差作为离散度的度量
绘制和解读箱形图和直方图
用统计量比较数据集

sections.title: Measures of Central Tendency
sections.content:
Mean (Average): Sum of all values / Number of values

Median: Middle value when data is ordered
- If n is odd: median is middle value
- If n is even: median is average of two middle values

Mode: Most frequently occurring value

Range: Highest value - Lowest value

Example: Test scores: 56, 78, 89, 67, 78, 92, 45, 78, 88

Ordered: 45, 56, 67, 78, 78, 78, 88, 89, 92
Mean = (45+56+67+78+78+78+88+89+92)/9 = 671/9 ≈ 74.6
Median = 78 (5th value)
Mode = 78 (appears 3 times)
Range = 92 - 45 = 47

When to use:
- Mean: Normal distribution, no extreme outliers
- Median: Skewed data or with outliers
- Mode: Categorical data or most popular item

sections.title: Standard Deviation
sections.content:
Standard deviation measures how spread out data is from the mean.

Small SD: Data clustered near mean
Large SD: Data spread out

Calculation steps:
1. Find mean (x̄)
2. Find each deviation from mean: (x - x̄)
3. Square each deviation: (x - x̄)²
4. Find mean of squared deviations: Σ(x - x̄)²/n
5. Take square root: SD = √[Σ(x - x̄)²/n]

Example: Test scores 70, 75, 80, 85, 90
Mean = 80
Deviations: -10, -5, 0, 5, 10
Squared: 100, 25, 0, 25, 100
Sum = 250
Variance = 250/5 = 50
SD = √50 ≈ 7.07

Interpretation:
Class A: Mean 75, SD 5 (consistent performance)
Class B: Mean 75, SD 15 (variable performance)

sections.title: Box Plots & Histograms
sections.content:
Box Plot (Box-and-Whisker):
Shows: Minimum, Q1, Median (Q2), Q3, Maximum

Quartiles divide data into 4 equal parts:
- Q1: 25th percentile
- Q2: 50th percentile (median)
- Q3: 75th percentile
- IQR (Interquartile Range) = Q3 - Q1

Outliers: Values beyond 1.5×IQR from Q1 or Q3

Histogram:
- Bar graph for continuous data
- X-axis: Class intervals
- Y-axis: Frequency or frequency density
- No gaps between bars
- Area represents frequency

Singapore context:
PSLE scores box plot shows:
- Minimum: 150
- Q1: 220
- Median: 250
- Q3: 270
- Maximum: 290
IQR = 270 - 220 = 50
Most students score between 220-270
